awd_titl_txt: The SRCOS Summer Research Conference in Statistics and Biostatistics
awd_abstract_narration:
The Southern Regional Council on Statistics is a consortium of statistics and biostatistics programs in the South. It currently has member programs at 45 universities in 16 states in the region. This grant will provide support for graduate and undergraduate students to travel and participate in the 56th Summer Research Conference (SRC) in statistics and biostatistics at Jekyll Island Villas by the Sea in Jekyll Island, Georgia on October 3-6, 2021. The SRC is an annual conference sponsored by the SRCOS. The purpose of the SRC is to encourage the interchange and mutual understanding of current research ideas in statistics and biostatistics, and to provide motivation and direction to further research progress.  This project will focus on young researchers, giving them an opportunity to participate in the meeting and to interact closely with leaders in the field in a manner not possible at larger meetings. The SRC is particularly valuable for graduate students, undergraduate students, isolated statisticians, and faculty from smaller regional schools in the southern region at drivable distances without the cost of travel to distant venues. Speakers will present formal research talks with adequate time allowed for clarification, amplification, and further informal discussions in small groups.  Under the travel support provided by this award, graduate students will attend and present their research in posters to be reviewed by more experienced researchers. 

In addition to the graduate student participation, the 56th SRC will also include the second annual Statistical Undergraduate Research Experience (SURE), a conference within a conference aimed to encourage the participation of undergraduate students from under-represented groups to pursue graduate education and career opportunities in STEM fields.  SURE will include events specifically for undergraduate students and undergraduate mentors, such as a panel about career opportunities in statistics, a “Real Data Analytics Workshop,” and a speed-mentoring session with current statistics and biostatistics graduate students. The support provided by this award will support SURE and encourage under-represented students to enter STEM fields, including statistics or biostatistics, and provide training to support this endeavor. The 56th SRC will strengthen the research of the statistics and biostatistics community as a whole and help bridge the gap for under-represented groups to pursue statistics or biostatistics, particularly in the sixteen states of the Southern Region. More information about the conference can be found at: https://www.srcos.org/conference.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Summer Research Conference (SRC) is an annual research conference sponsored by the Southern Regional Council on Statistics (SRCOS). Since the inception of the SRC, the purposes of the conference are to encourage the interchange and mutual understanding of research ideas in statistics and biostatistics, and to give motivation and direction to further research progress, particularly for young researchers, in a manner not ordinarily possible at other meetings. The meeting is particularly valuable for graduate students, isolated statisticians, and faculty from smaller regional schools in the Southern Region. Each year, the location of the conference is chosen to be at a drivable distance for researchers in the Southern Region, thus affording them the opportunity to participate and interact closely with internationally known leaders in the field without the cost of travel to distant venues. Speakers present formal research talks with adequate time allowed for clarification, amplification, and further informal discussions in small groups. As such, speakers, session chairs, and discussants make themselves accessible for informal discussions of their research as well as formal presentations.

 

The 56th Annual Summer Research Conference (SRC) was held October 2nd  - October 5th, 2021 in Jekyll Island, Georgia. It was co-organized by the Southern Regional Council on Statistics (SRCOS) and Emory University. 94 scholars from institutions across the country (Alabama to South Dakota, the Carolinas to Arizona) participated. The website for the meeting (www.srcos.org) contains program details, abstracts, and photos of conference activities. Thanks to NSF support for students, limited SRCOS funds from registrations and membership fees could be used to provide support for Dr. Kathy Ensor, ASA President (Rice University) to attend and give two keynote talks. The conference featured five additional stimulating invited oral sessions, featuring outstanding faculty speakers at both the senior and junior levels.

 

Within the 2021 SRC, SRCOS also held its second undergraduate portion of their Summer Research Conference.  PI Thompson directed the program, and Co-PI Stromberg was an invited panelist and crucial contributor to the advertisement, plans, and implementation of the program. In total, 35 undergraduate students participated in SURE, a conference within the 2021 SRC.  More than 60% of these participants were women or from under-represented groups.  The students were engaged, attending sessions alongside graduate students and faculty at the SRC, but also participating in SURE-specific sessions.  These SURE-specific sessions included a graduate school and career information session, a graduate student mentoring session, and a data analytics workshop.

 

After hearing information about graduate school and careers in statistics and data analytics, Graduate Student Facilitators (Greg Hawk and Leon Su) led a mentoring session, where trios including one current graduate student and two undergraduate students asked and answered questions about graduate school.  In this session, students interacted without faculty and undergraduates were able to ask questions that they may not have had another opportunity to ask about graduate education in STEM.

 

The last SURE-specific event was a data analytics workshop led by PI Thompson with the help of other faculty (Co-PI Stromberg, SRCOS President Elect Ed Boone, and the Graduate Student Facilitators.  Students used publicly available Airbnb data to create both plots and geographic visualizations of the data, which they then used to identify listing characteristics related to the price and/or quality of the rental.  Students worked in both JMP and R as a group, but then explored the data further using one of these software packages based on their own preferences.  Methods and code were provided for both new and experienced programmers.  By using both types of software, the workshop was able to provide differentiated instructional opportunities to a multidisciplinary group of STEM students.

 

The NSF/R.L. Anderson Student Poster Session featured poster presentations from 30 graduate students, representing many graduate programs across the Southern Region.  Travel awards were provided by funding from the National Science Foundation, with additional support from the American Statistical Association (ASA) and SRCOS. These awards enabled students, in many cases representing programs with limited travel budgets, to experience a significant scientific conference firsthand. They interacted closely with leading researchers in the field in a manner that is not possible at larger national or international meetings. The recipient of the M. Clinton Miller Graduate Student Poster Award was Eric Yachenko (North Carolina State University), and of the R.L. Anderson Graduate Student Poster Award: Elizabeth Amona (Virginia Commonwealth University) and Suman Majumder (North Carolina State University).

 

Eight junior faculty received Kutner/ASA poster awards.  In addition to a generous contribution from Mike Kutner, funds from ASA, SRCOS, Statistical and Applied Mathematical Sciences Institute (SAMSI), and the National Institute of Statistical Sciences (NISS) Affiliates Fund helped defray the cost of attendance for these faculty participants. The winners of the 2021 seventh annual Mike Kutner/ASA Best Poster Award for a Junior Faculty Member were Dr. Jonathan Stewart (Florida State University) and Dr. Joshua Lukemire (Emory University).
